content.raw:
I think this function could be simplified to:

`return user in this.sockets ? this.sockets : [];`
content.html:

content.raw: All this socket stuff should go into an angularjs service. I'll take a pass at it.
content.html: All this socket stuff should go into an angularjs service. I'll take a pass at it.

content.raw: This is extra text that will be sent everytime a page is loaded. I think the `<script>` line is self-explanatory, and we could do without the comment.
content.html: This is extra text that will be sent everytime a page is loaded. I think the <script> line is self-explanatory, and we could do without the comment.

Update: we are going to use 

// from mongo dates
new Date("2014-04-04T20:57:49.083Z");

// And for generating time (instead of UTC)
new Date().toISOString()

for now

content.raw:
Good point, and I've tried Date.parse 

I'm not sure that that unix timestamps are the answer, they may not work on Windows for example. 
also, in the REST API, we have textual dates from mongo in text format:  (ex: "date_launch": "2014-04-03T23:23:23.404Z").

We need to find a string_to_date and a date_to_string we can use everywhere.
content.html:
Good point, and I've tried Date.parse

I'm not sure that that unix timestamps are the answer, they may not work on Windows for example. also, in the REST API, we have textual dates from mongo in text format: (ex: "date_launch": "2014-04-03T23:23:23.404Z").

We need to find a string_to_date and a date_to_string we can use everywhere.

content.raw: add `socketDict.getSockets('Alice').should.be.instanceof(Array).and.have.lengthOf(1);` here to make sure we have the socket?
content.html: add socketDict.getSockets('Alice').should.be.instanceof(Array).and.have.lengthOf(1); here to make sure we have the socket?

content.raw: just send unix timestamp? (without the `.toUTCString()`) otherwise its hard to parse on the client side
